revision.text:
{{Short description|constellation in the Southern Celestial Hemisphere}} {{Featured article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox constellation | name = Antlia | abbreviation = Ant | genitive = Antliae | pronounce = {{IPAc-en|ˈ|æ|n|t|l|i|ə}}, genitive {{IPAc-en|-|l|i|i}} | symbolism = the Air Pump{{cite book |last=Bakich |first=Michael E. |date=1995 |title=The Cambridge Guide to the Constellations |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge, United Kingdom |isbn=978-0-521-44921-2 |url=https://archive.org/details/cambridgeguideto00baki }} | RA = {{RA|09|27|05.1837}}–{{RA|11|05|55.0471}}{{Cite journal | title=Antlia, constellation boundary | journal=The Constellations |url=http://www.iau.org/public/constellations/#ant | accessdate=14 February 2014 }} | dec= {{dec|-24.5425186}}–{{dec|-40.4246216}} | family = [[La Caille Family|La Caille]] | areatotal = 239 | arearank = 62nd | numbermainstars = 3 | numberbfstars = 9 | numberstarsplanets = 2 | numberbrightstars = 0 | numbernearbystars = 2 | brighteststarname = [[Alpha Antliae|α Ant]] | starmagnitude = 4.25 | neareststarname = [[DEN 1048-3956]]{{cite web |url = http://www.recons.org/TOP100.posted.htm |title = The 100 Nearest Star Systems |date = 1 January 2012 |accessdate =2 May 2016 |publisher = Research Consortium on Nearby Stars}} | stardistancely = 13.17 | stardistancepc = 4.04 | numbermessierobjects = 0 | meteorshowers = None | bordering = [[Hydra (constellation)|Hydra]]
[[Pyxis]]
[[Vela (constellation)|Vela]]
[[Centaurus]] | latmax = [[45th parallel north|45]] | latmin = [[South Pole|90]] | month = April | notes=}} '''Antlia''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|æ|n|t|l|i|ə}}; from [[Ancient Greek]] ''ἀντλία'') is a [[constellation]] in the [[Southern Celestial Hemisphere]]. Its name means "[[pump]]" in [[Latin]]; it represents an [[air pump]]. Originally '''Antlia Pneumatica''', the constellation was established by [[Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille]] in the 18th century, though its name was later abbreviated by [[John Herschel]]. Located close to the stars forming the old constellation of the ship [[Argo Navis]], Antlia is completely visible from latitudes south of [[49th parallel north|49 degrees north]]. Antlia is a faint constellation; its brightest star is [[Alpha Antliae]], an orange [[giant star|giant]] that is a suspected [[variable star]], ranging between [[apparent magnitude]]s 4.22 and 4.29. [[S Antliae]] is an [[Binary star#Eclipsing binaries|eclipsing binary]] star system, changing in brightness as one star passes in front of the other. Sharing a [[common envelope]], the stars are so close they will one day merge to form a single star. Two star systems with known exoplanets, [[HD 93083]] and [[WASP-66]], lie within Antlia, as do [[NGC 2997]], a [[spiral galaxy]], and the [[Antlia Dwarf|Antlia Dwarf Galaxy]]. ==History== [[File:Antlia bode.JPG|thumb|border|upright=1.38|left|Johann Bode's depiction of Antlia as a double-cylinder air pump]] The French astronomer [[Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille]] first described the constellation in French as ''la Machine Pneumatique'' (the Pneumatic Machine) in 1751–52,{{cite web |url=http://www.ianridpath.com/startales/lacaille.htm |title=Lacaille's Southern Planisphere of 1756 |work=Star Tales |author=Ridpath, Ian |author-link=Ian Ridpath |publisher=Self-published |accessdate=25 August 2015}}{{cite journal |author=Lacaille, Nicolas Louis |date=1756 |title=Relation abrégée du Voyage fait par ordre du Roi au cap de Bonne-espérance |journal=Mémoires de l'Académie Royale des Sciences |pages=519–592 [589] |url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k35505/f787 |language=French}} commemorating the [[air pump]] invented by the French physicist [[Denis Papin]].{{cite web |last = Ridpath |first = Ian |work= Star Tales |title= Antlia |url=http://www.ianridpath.com/startales/antlia.htm |accessdate=3 December 2007| url-status= live}} De Lacaille had observed and catalogued almost 10,000 southern stars during a two-year stay at the [[Cape of Good Hope]], devising fourteen new constellations in uncharted regions of the [[Southern Celestial Hemisphere]] not visible from Europe. He named all but one in honour of instruments that symbolised the [[Age of Enlightenment]].{{efn|1=The exception is [[Mensa (constellation)|Mensa]], named for the [[Table Mountain]]. The other thirteen (alongside Antlia) are [[Caelum]], [[Circinus]], [[Fornax]], [[Horologium (constellation)|Horologium]], [[Microscopium]], [[Norma (constellation)|Norma]], [[Octans]], [[Pictor]], [[Pyxis]], [[Reticulum]], [[Sculptor (constellation)|Sculptor]] and [[Telescopium]].{{sfn|Wagman|2003|pp=5–6}} }}{{sfn|Wagman|2003|pp=5–6}} Lacaille depicted Antlia as a single-cylinder vacuum pump used in Papin's initial experiments, while German astronomer [[Johann Elert Bode|Johann Bode]] chose the more advanced double-cylinder version. Lacaille [[Latin]]ised the name to ''Antlia pneumatica'' on his 1763 chart. English astronomer [[John Herschel]] proposed shrinking the name to one word in 1844, noting that Lacaille himself had abbreviated his constellations thus on occasion.{{cite journal | author=Herschel, John | year=1844 | journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society | volume=6 | issue=5 | pages=60–62 | title=Farther Remarks on the Division of Southern Constellations | url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=s-tBAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA62 | doi = 10.1093/mnras/6.5.60a}} This was universally adopted.{{sfn|Wagman|2003|p=25}} The [[International Astronomical Union]] adopted it as one of the [[88 modern constellations]] in 1922. Although visible to the [[Ancient Greek astronomy|Ancient Greeks]], Antlia's stars were too faint to have been included in any ancient constellations. The stars that now comprise Antlia lay within an area of the sky covered by the ancient constellation [[Argo Navis]], the Ship of the Argonauts, which due to its immense size was split into several smaller constellations by Lacaille in 1763.{{cite book | author= Birren, Peter | year= 2002|title= Objects in the Heavens|pages= 9, 45 |publisher=Trafford Publishing |location=Bloomington, Indiana |isbn= 978-1-55369-662-9}}{{cite book |author=Webb, Thomas William |publisher=Dover Publications |location=New York, New York |date=1962 |title=Celestial objects for common telescopes |volume=2 |page=[https://archive.org/details/celestialobjects00webb/page/36 36] |isbn=978-0-486-20918-0 |url=https://archive.org/details/celestialobjects00webb/page/36 }} Ridpath reports that due to their faintness, the stars of Antlia did not make up part of the classical depiction of Argo Navis.{{cite book | author=Ridpath, Ian |year=2002|title= Stars and Planets|pages= 65, 122 | publisher=Smithsonian Handbooks | location=New York, New York |isbn= 978-0-7894-8988-3}} ===In non-Western astronomy=== [[Chinese astronomy|Chinese astronomers]] were able to view what is modern Antlia from their latitudes, and incorporated its stars into two different constellations. Several stars in the southern part of Antlia were a portion of "''Dong'ou''", which represented an area in southern China. Furthermore, [[Epsilon Antliae|Epsilon]], [[Eta Antliae|Eta]], and [[Theta Antliae]] were incorporated into the celestial temple, which also contained stars from modern [[Pyxis]]. ==Characteristics== Covering 238.9 square degrees and hence 0.579% of the sky, Antlia ranks 62nd of the [[88 modern constellations]] by area.{{cite web| url=http://www.ianridpath.com/constellations1.htm | title=Constellations: Andromeda–Indus | work= Star Tales |author=Ridpath, Ian |author-link=Ian Ridpath|publisher=self-published | accessdate= 26 August 2015}} Its position in the [[Southern Celestial Hemisphere]] means that the whole [[constellation]] is visible to observers south of [[49th parallel north|49°N]].{{efn|1=Although parts of the constellation technically rise above the horizon to observers between the 49°N and [[65th parallel north|65°N]], stars within a few degrees of the horizon are to all intents and purposes unobservable.}} [[Hydra (constellation)|Hydra]] the sea snake runs along the length of its northern border, while [[Pyxis]] the compass, [[Vela (constellation)|Vela]] the sails, and [[Centaurus]] the centaur line it to the west, south and east respectively. The three-letter abbreviation for the constellation, as adopted by the International Astronomical Union, is "Ant".{{cite journal | last=Russell | first=Henry Norris |author-link=Henry Norris Russell | title=The New International Symbols for the Constellations | journal=[[Popular Astronomy (US magazine)|Popular Astronomy]] | volume=30 | page=469 | bibcode=1922PA.....30..469R | date=1922 }} The official constellation boundaries, as set by Belgian astronomer [[Eugène Joseph Delporte|Eugène Delporte]] in 1930,{{efn|1=Delporte had proposed standardising the constellation boundaries to the International Astronomical Union, who had agreed and gave him the lead role{{cite web| url=http://www.ianridpath.com/constellations1.htm | title=Constellation boundaries: How the modern constellation outlines came to be| work= Star Tales |author=Ridpath, Ian |author-link=Ian Ridpath|publisher=self-published | accessdate= 1 June 2016}}}} are defined by a polygon with an east side, south side and ten other sides (facing the two other cardinal compass points) (''illustrated in infobox at top-right''). In the [[equatorial coordinate system]], the [[right ascension]] coordinates of these borders lie between {{RA|09|26.5}} and {{RA|11|05.6}}, while the [[declination]] coordinates are between −24.54° and −40.42°. ==Features== [[Image:Constellation Antlia.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.38|The constellation Antlia as seen by the naked eye]] ===Stars=== {{See also|List of stars in Antlia}} Lacaille gave nine stars [[Bayer designation]]s, labelling them Alpha through to Theta, combining two stars next to each other as Zeta. Gould later added a tenth, [[Iota Antliae]]. Beta and Gamma Antliae (now [[HR 4339]] and [[HD 90156]]) ended up in the neighbouring constellation Hydra once the constellation boundaries were delineated in 1930.{{sfn|Wagman|2003|p=29}} Within the constellation's borders, there are 42 stars brighter than or equal to [[apparent magnitude]] 6.5.{{efn|1=Objects of magnitude 6.5 are among the faintest visible to the unaided eye in suburban-rural transition night skies.{{cite web|url=http://www.skyandtelescope.com/resources/darksky/3304011.html?page=1&c=y|title=The Bortle Dark-Sky Scale|last=Bortle|first=John E.|date=February 2001|work=[[Sky & Telescope]]|accessdate=26 August 2015}}}} The constellation's two brightest stars—[[Alpha Antliae|Alpha]] and [[Epsilon Antliae]]—shine with a reddish tinge.{{cite book|author1=Arnold, H.J.P. |author2=Doherty, Paul |author3=Moore, Patrick |title=The Photographic Atlas of the Stars|publisher=CRC Press|location=Boca Raton, Florida|date=1999|page=97 |isbn=978-0-7503-0654-6|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=YjcvJUfnWBAC&pg=PA97}} Alpha is an orange [[giant star|giant]] of [[Stellar classification#Spectral types|spectral type]] [[Stellar classification#Class K|K4III]] that is a suspected [[variable star]], ranging between [[apparent magnitude]]s 4.22 and 4.29.{{cite web|url=http://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?view=detail.top&oid=43486 |title=Alpha Antliae |author =Watson, Christopher |date=18 January 2010 |work=AAVSO Website|publisher=American Association of Variable Star Observers|accessdate=25 July 2014}} It is located 320 ± 10 [[light-year]]s away from Earth.{{cite DR2|5449188358926934016}} Estimated to be shining with around 480 to 555 times the [[luminosity]] of the Sun, it is most likely an ageing star that is brightening and on its way to becoming a [[Mira variable]] star, having converted all its core fuel into carbon.{{cite web| first1=James B. | last1=Kaler | title=Alpha Antliae| work=Stars | publisher=University of Illinois | url=http://stars.astro.illinois.edu/sow/alphaant.html | accessdate=25 July 2014}} Located 590 ± 30 light-years from Earth,{{cite DR2|5437183238144337408}} Epsilon Antliae is an evolved orange giant star of spectral type K3 IIIa, that has swollen to have a diameter about 69 times that of the Sun,{{cite journal | last1=Pasinetti-Fracassini | first1=L.E. | last2=Pastori | first2=L. | last3=Covino | first3=S. | last4=Pozzi | first4=A. | title=Catalogue of Stellar Diameters (CADARS) | journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics | volume=367 | issue=2 | pages=521–24 |date=February 2001 | doi=10.1051/0004-6361:20000451 | bibcode=2001A&A...367..521P | arxiv=astro-ph/0012289}} and a luminosity of around 1279 Suns.{{cite journal|author=McDonald, I.|author2=Zijlstra, A. A.|author3=Boyer, M. L.|date=2012|title=Fundamental Parameters and Infrared Excesses of Hipparcos Stars|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|volume=427|issue=1|pages=343–57|bibcode=2012MNRAS.427..343M|arxiv = 1208.2037 |doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2966.2012.21873.x }} It is slightly variable.{{cite journal | last1=Koen | first1=Chris | last2=Eyer | first2=Laurent | title=New Periodic Variables from the Hipparcos Epoch Photometry | journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society | volume=331 | issue=1 | pages=45–59 |date=March 2002 | doi=10.1046/j.1365-8711.2002.05150.x | bibcode=2002MNRAS.331...45K |arxiv = astro-ph/0112194 }} At the other end of Antlia, [[Iota Antliae]] is likewise an orange giant of spectral type K1 III.{{cite web |url = http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=Iota+Ant&NbIdent=1&Radius=2&Radius.unit=arcmin&submit=submit+id |title = Iota Antliae |work = SIMBAD Astronomical Database|publisher=Centre de Données astronomiques de Strasbourg |accessdate = 29 July 2014}} It is 202 ± 2 light-years distant.{{cite DR2|5394951821153092864}} Located near Alpha is [[Delta Antliae]], a [[binary star]], 450 ± 10 light-years distant from Earth.{{cite DR2|5449301299387283200}} The primary is a [[B-type main sequence star|blue-white main sequence star]] of spectral type [[Stellar classification#Class B|B9.5V]] and magnitude 5.6, and the secondary is a [[F-type main sequence star|yellow-white main sequence star]] of spectral type [[Stellar classification#Class F|F9Ve]] and magnitude 9.6.{{cite journal | last1=Huélamo | first1=N. | last2=Neuhäuser | first2=R. | last3=Stelzer | first3=B. | last4=Supper | first4=R. | last5=Zinnecker | first5=H. | title=X-ray emission from Lindroos binary systems | journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics | volume=359 | pages=227–41 |date=July 2000 | bibcode=2000A&A...359..227H |arxiv = astro-ph/0005348 }} [[Zeta Antliae]] is a wide optical [[double star]]. The brighter star—[[Zeta1 Antliae|Zeta1 Antliae]]—is 410 ± 40 light-years distant and has a magnitude of 5.74,{{cite journal | title=Validation of the new Hipparcos reduction | url=http://www.aanda.org/index.php?option=com_article&access=bibcode&Itemid=129&bibcode=2007A%2526A...474..653VFUL | last1=van Leeuwen | first1=F. | journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics | volume=474 | issue=2 | pages=653–64 | date=2007 | arxiv=0708.1752 | bibcode=2007A&A...474..653V | doi=10.1051/0004-6361:20078357 }} though it is a true binary star system composed of two [[A-type main sequence star|white main sequence stars]] of magnitudes 6.20 and 7.01 that are separated by 8.042 [[arcsecond]]s.{{cite journal | last1=Eggleton | first1=P. P. | last2=Tokovinin | first2=A. A. | title=A catalogue of multiplicity among bright stellar systems | journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] | volume=389 | issue=2 | pages=869–79 |date=September 2008 | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2008.13596.x | bibcode=2008MNRAS.389..869E |arxiv = 0806.2878 }} The fainter star—[[Zeta2 Antliae|Zeta2 Antliae]]—is 386 ± 5 light-years distant{{cite DR2|5632041952992756992}} and of magnitude 5.9.{{Harvnb|Ridpath|2017|pp=76–78}} [[Eta Antliae]] is another double composed of a yellow white star of spectral type F1V and magnitude 5.31, with a companion of magnitude 11.3. [[Theta Antliae]] is likewise double, most likely composed of an [[A-type main sequence star]] and a yellow giant.{{cite web| first1=James B. | last1=Kaler | title=Theta Antliae| work=Stars | publisher=University of Illinois | url=http://stars.astro.illinois.edu/sow/thetaant.html | date= 12 April 2013| accessdate=25 March 2016}} [[S Antliae]] is an [[eclipsing binary]] star system that varies in apparent magnitude from 6.27 to 6.83 over a period of 15.6 hours.{{cite web|url=http://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?view=detail.top&oid=444 |title=S Antliae |author =Watson, Christopher |date=4 January 2010 |work=AAVSO Website|publisher=American Association of Variable Star Observers|accessdate=22 May 2014}} The system is classed as a [[W Ursae Majoris variable]]—the primary is hotter than the secondary and the drop in magnitude is caused by the latter passing in front of the former. Calculating the properties of the component stars from the orbital period indicates that the primary star has a mass 1.94 times and a diameter 2.026 times that of the Sun, and the secondary has a mass 0.76 times and a diameter 1.322 times that of the Sun.{{cite journal| title=Angular momentum and mass evolution of contact binaries |author1=Gazeas, K. |author2=Stȩpień, K. | journal = Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society| volume = 390| issue= 4| pages= 1577–86 | year= 2008 | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2008.13844.x | bibcode= 2008MNRAS.390.1577G|arxiv = 0803.0212 }} The two stars have similar [[luminosity]] and [[stellar classification|spectral type]] as they have a [[common envelope]] and share stellar material.{{cite journal| title=On the properties of contact binary stars |author1=Csizmadia, Sz. |author2=Klagyivik, P. |journal = Astronomy and Astrophysics| volume= 426|issue=3 | pages=1001–05 |date=2004| doi=10.1051/0004-6361:20040430 | bibcode =2004A&A...426.1001C|arxiv = astro-ph/0408049 }} The system is thought to be around 5–6 billion years old. The two stars will eventually merge to form a single fast-spinning star. [[T Antliae]] is a [[Yellow supergiant|yellow-white supergiant]] of spectral type F6Iab and [[Classical Cepheid variable]] ranging between magnitude 8.88 and 9.82 over 5.9 days.{{cite web|url=http://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?view=detail.top&oid=445 |title=T Antliae |author =Watson, Christopher |date=4 January 2010 |work=AAVSO Website|publisher=American Association of Variable Star Observers|accessdate=25 July 2014}} [[U Antliae]] is a red [[stellar classification|C-type]] [[carbon star]] and is an [[irregular variable]] that ranges between magnitudes 5.27 and 6.04.{{cite web|url=http://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?view=detail.top&oid=446 |title=U Antliae |author =Otero, Sebastian |date=3 November 2011 |work=AAVSO Website|publisher=American Association of Variable Star Observers|accessdate=25 July 2014}} At 910 ± 50 light-years distant,{{cite DR2|5440991156144997504}} it is around 5819 times as luminous as the Sun. [[BF Antliae]] is a [[Delta Scuti variable]] that varies by 0.01 of a magnitude.{{cite journal | title=Statistical Properties of Galactic δ Scuti Stars: Revisited | author=Chang, S.-W. | author2=Protopapas, P. | author3=Kim, D.-W. | author4=Byun, Y.-I. | journal =The Astronomical Journal |volume = 145 |issue= 5 | id= 132|pages= 10|date=2013|doi=10.1088/0004-6256/145/5/132 |bibcode=2013AJ....145..132C|arxiv = 1303.1031 }} [[HR 4049]], also known as AG Antliae, is an unusual hot variable ageing star of spectral type B9.5Ib-II. It is undergoing intense loss of mass{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1086/185431| title = Unusual features of the 1–4 micron spectrum of HR 4049 | journal = The Astrophysical Journal| volume = 340 | pages = L29 | date = 1989| last1 = Geballe | first1 = T.R.| last2 = Noll | first2 = K.S.| last3 = Whittet | first3 = D.C.B.| last4 = Waters | first4 = L.B.F.M. |bibcode = 1989ApJ...340L..29G }} and is a unique variable that does not belong to any class of known variable star, ranging between magnitudes 5.29 and 5.83 with a period of 429 days.{{cite web|url=http://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?view=detail.top&oid=503 |title=AG Antliae |author=VSX|date=4 January 2010|work=The International Variable Star Index |publisher=American Association of Variable Star Observers|accessdate=15 June 2013}} It is around 6000 light-years away from Earth.{{cite DR2|5462428643590805248}} [[UX Antliae]] is an [[R Coronae Borealis variable]] with a baseline apparent magnitude of around 11.85, with irregular dimmings down to below magnitude 18.0.{{ cite web | title= UX Ant| work=The International Variable Star Index | url=http://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?view=detail.top&oid=479| author=Otero, Sebastian | date=23 November 2012 | accessdate=14 July 2014}} A luminous and remote star, it is a [[supergiant]] with a spectrum resembling that of a yellow-white F-type star but it has almost no hydrogen.{{cite journal|author=Kilkenny, D.|author2=Westerhuys, J. E. |date=1990|title= Spectroscopy of 'RCB' stars-IV. UX ANT |journal= The Observatory|volume=110 |pages=90–92|bibcode = 1990Obs...110...90K }} [[File:NGC 2997 ESO.jpg|thumb|border|right|upright=1.38|A composite image of NGC 2997]] [[HD 93083]] is an orange dwarf star of spectral type K3V that is smaller and cooler than the Sun. It has a planet that was discovered by the [[radial velocity method]] with the [[High Accuracy Radial Velocity Planet Searcher|HARPS spectrograph]] in 2005. About as massive as Saturn, the planet orbits its star with a period of 143 days at a mean distance of 0.477 AU.{{cite journal | title=The HARPS search for southern extra-solar planets III. Three Saturn-mass planets around HD 93083, HD 101930 and HD 102117 | url=http://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full/2005/27/aa2864-05/aa2864-05.html | last1=Lovis | first1=C. | last2=Mayor | first2=M. | last3=Bouchy | first3=F. | last4=Pepe | first4=F. | last5=Queloz | first5=D. | last6=Santos | first6=N.C. | last7=Udry | first7=S. | last8=Benz | first8=W. | last9=Bertaux | first9=J.-L. | last10=Mordasini | first10=C. | last11=Sivan | first11=J.-P. | journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics | volume=437 | issue=3 | pages=1121–26 | date=2005 | arxiv=astro-ph/0503660 | bibcode=2005A&A...437.1121L | doi=10.1051/0004-6361:20052864 }} [[WASP-66]] is a sunlike star of spectral type F4V. A planet with 2.3 times the mass of Jupiter orbits it every 4 days, discovered by the transit method in 2012.{{cite journal|author=Hellier, Coel|author2=Anderson, D. R.|author3=Collier Cameron, A.|author4=Doyle, A. P.|author5=Fumel, A.|author6=Gillon, M.|author7=Jehin, E.|author8=Lendl, M.|author9=Maxted, P. F. L.|author10=Pepe, F.|author11=Pollacco, D.|author12=Queloz, D.|author13=Ségransan, D.|author14=Smalley, B.|author15=Smith, A. M. S.|author16=Southworth, J.|author17=Triaud, A. H. M. J.|author18=Udry, S.|author19=West, R. G.|date=2012|title=Seven transiting hot Jupiters from WASP-South, Euler and TRAPPIST: WASP-47b, WASP-55b, WASP-61b, WASP-62b, WASP-63b, WASP-66b and WASP-67b|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|volume=426|issue=1|pages=439–50|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2012.21780.x|bibcode=2012MNRAS.426..739H|arxiv = 1204.5095 }} [[DEN 1048-3956]] is a [[brown dwarf]] of spectral type M8 located around 13 light-years distant from Earth. At magnitude 17 it is much too faint to be seen with the unaided eye. It has a surface temperature of about 2500 K. Two powerful [[Solar flare|flares]] lasting 4–5 minutes each were detected in 2002.{{ cite journal | url=http://www.iop.org/EJ/abstract/0004-637X/626/1/486/ | title=Quiescent Radio Emission from Southern Late-Type M Dwarfs and a Spectacular Radio Flare from the M8 Dwarf DENIS 1048–3956 | author= Burgasser, Adam J. | author2= Putman, Mary E. | journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]] | date=10 June 2005 | volume=626 | issue=1 | pages=486–497 | doi=10.1086/429788 | bibcode=2005ApJ...626..486B|arxiv = astro-ph/0502365 }} [[2MASS 0939-2448]] is a system of two cool and faint brown dwarfs, probably with effective temperatures of about 500 and 700 K and masses of about 25 and 40 times that of Jupiter, though it is also possible that both objects have temperatures of 600 K and 30 Jupiter masses.{{cite journal |last1=Leggett |first1=S. K. |last2=Cushing |first2=Michael C. |last3=Saumon |first3=D. |last4=Marley |first4=M. S. |last5=Roellig |first5=T. L. |last6=Warren |first6=S. J. |last7=Burningham |first7=Ben |last8=Jones |first8=H. R. A. |last9=Kirkpatrick |first9=J. D. |last10=Lodieu |first10=N. |last11=Lucas |first11=P. W. |last12=Mainzer |first12=A. K. |last13=Martín |first13=E. L. |last14=McCaughrean |first14=M. J. |last15=Pinfield |first15=D. J. |last16=Sloan |first16=G. C. |last17=Smart |first17=R. L. |last18=Tamura |first18=M. |last19=Van Cleve |first19=J. |title=The Physical Properties of Four ~600 K T Dwarfs |date=2009 |journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]] |volume=695| issue=2 | pages=1517–1526 |arxiv=0901.4093 |doi=10.1088/0004-637X/695/2/1517 |bibcode=2009ApJ...695.1517L}} ===Deep-sky objects=== [[File:ESO 376-16.jpg|thumb|left|Galaxy [[ESO 376-16]] is located nearly 23 million light-years from Earth.{{cite web|title=Mapping the nearby Universe|url=https://www.spacetelescope.org/images/potw1739a/|website=www.spacetelescope.org|accessdate=25 September 2017}}]] Antlia contains many faint galaxies, the brightest of which is [[NGC 2997]] at magnitude 10.6.{{Harvnb|Moore|Tirion|1997}} It is a loosely wound face-on [[spiral galaxy]] of type [[Galaxy morphological classification|Sc]]. Though nondescript in most amateur telescopes, it presents bright clusters of young stars and many dark dust lanes in photographs. Discovered in 1997, the [[Antlia Dwarf]] is a 14.8m [[dwarf spheroidal galaxy]] that belongs to the [[Local Group]] of galaxies.{{Cite APOD |title =Antlia: A New Galactic Neighbor |access-date =9 April 2012 |date=23 April 1997 }} In 2018 the discovery was announced of a very low [[surface brightness]] galaxy near Epsilon Antliae, [[Antlia 2]], which is a satellite galaxy of the Milky Way.{{cite arXiv|eprint=1811.04082 |last1=Torrealba |first1=G. |title=The hidden giant: Discovery of an enormous Galactic dwarf satellite in Gaia DR2 |last2=Belokurov |first2=V. |last3=Koposov |first3=S. E. |last4=Li |first4=T. S. |last5=Walker |first5=M. G. |last6=Sanders |first6=J. L. |last7=Geringer-Sameth |first7=A. |last8=Zucker |first8=D. B. |last9=Kuehn |first9=K. |last10=Evans |first10=N. W. |last11=Dehnen |first11=W. |class=astro-ph.GA |year=2018 }} The [[Antlia Cluster]], also known as Abell S0636, is a [[galaxy cluster|cluster of galaxies]] located in the [[Hydra-Centaurus Supercluster]]. It is the third nearest to the [[Local Group]] after the [[Virgo Cluster]] and the [[Fornax Cluster]].{{Cite journal | last1 = Smith Castelli | first1 = Analía V. | last2 = Bassino | first2 = Lilia P. | last3 = Richtler | first3 = Tom | last4 = Cellone | first4 = Sergio A. | last5 = Aruta | first5 = Cristian | last6 = Infante | first6 = Leopoldo | title = Galaxy populations in the Antlia cluster – I. Photometric properties of early-type galaxies |date=June 2008 | journal = [[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] | volume = 386 | issue = 4 | pages = 2311–22 | doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2966.2008.13211.x | bibcode = 2008MNRAS.386.2311S|arxiv = 0803.1630 }} The cluster's distance from earth is {{convert|40.5|Mpc|Mly|1|lk=on|abbr=on}} to {{convert|40.9|Mpc|Mly|1|lk=off|abbr=on}}{{cite journal | last1 = Dirsch | first1 = B. | last2 = Richtler | first2 = T. | last3 = Bassino | first3 = L.P. |date=2003 | title = The globular cluster systems of NGC 3258 and NGC 3268 in the Antlia cluster | journal = [[Astronomy and Astrophysics]] | volume = 408 | issue = 3 | pages = 929–39| doi = 10.1051/0004-6361:20031027 | bibcode = 2003A&A...408..929D |arxiv = astro-ph/0307200}} Located in the southeastern corner of the constellation, it boasts the giant elliptical galaxies [[NGC 3268]] and [[NGC 3258]] as the main members of a southern and northern subgroup respectively, and contains around 234 galaxies in total.{{cite journal | last = Streicher | first = Magda | date = 2010 | title = Deepsky Delights: Antlia, the Machine Pneumatique | journal = Monthly Notes of the Astronomical Society of Southern Africa |volume=69 |issue=5–6 |pages = 107–12 | bibcode=2010MNSSA..69..107S}} {{Clear}} == Notes == {{Notelist}} ==
